text: the Court of Appeal has ruled that one
of three London schoolgirls who left
five years ago to join the Islamic state
group in Syria should be allowed to
return to the UK so she can challenge a
decision to strip her of her British
nationality in person Shamima Begum who
is now 20 is unable to leave Syria after
her citizenship was revoked last year or
Home Affairs correspondent Daniel
Sanford has more
this was Shamima Begum when she first
reimbursed last year having gone to join
the Islamic state group four years
earlier aged just 15 when the BBC
interviewed her is had collapsed in
Syria and she was asking to come back to
Britain I just want forgiveness really
from the UK like everything I've been
through I didn't expect I would go
through that and you know losing my
children the way I lost them but with
the public divided between those who
felt she'd been groomed and those who
wanted her barred from Britain
the Home Secretary took away her
citizenship leaving her stranded a
decision she had been fighting from the
AL Raj camp for is women in Northeast
Syria but the appeal court said today
that she should be allowed to come to
the UK talk properly to her lawyers and
fight her case in person Lord Justice
flow said whilst she remains detained in
the camp she cannot give effective
instructions the only way in which she
can have a fair and effective appeal is
to be permitted to come in to the United
Kingdom the judges heard that because
she's in the camp Shamima Begum's
lawyers cannot even get hold of her by
telephone to discuss the evidence
against her they said achieving fairness
in this case should outweigh any
national security concerns obviously we
were disappointed with the decision and
the Home Office will be appealing it
beyond that it's an ongoing legal matter
sirs not much more I can say Shamima
Begum left Britain in February 2015 with
two school friends travelling through
Turkey to iose territory in Syria where
they married fighters her two friends
are believed to be dead the lawyer for
her mother and sisters told me they were
relieved that they might yet see her
again
well they're certainly heartened by the
decision today is a step further towards
Sheila Megan potentially coming back it
to the UK and being safe and speaking by
phone from Bangladesh her father was
also pleased I certainly welcome the
court's decision I hope she gets justice
I'm happy and every father would welcome
this but the Home Office insists Ramiro
Begum is a threat to national security
and while the Home Secretary tries to
overturn today's decision at the Supreme
Court she will remain in Northeast Syria
Daniel Sanford BBC news
